data.title: Navigate to next/previous symbolic match in file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Similarly to the navigation in textual matches: The editor could offer navigation between symbolic matches.

E.g., I often find myself with the text cursor on a symbol, looking at the overview ruler to see the other occurrences of that symbol and wanting to navigate through these. Currently I have to use the mouse to click through the other occurrences in the overview ruler, it would be great to have a way to do the same with the keyboard.

data.title: Syntax coloring for "yield" keyword
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home

The `yield` keyword needs to be highlighted just like `await`. There are 2 cases here:
```js
yield doSomethingThatDoesNotReturn(); // The yield here is highlighted correctly.

const result = yield doSomething(); // The yield here is **NOT** highlighted.
```

Note that I was using **Light (Visual Studio)** theme.

data.title: Theme selection palette broken
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0-insider, 80481e
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the color theme selection palette
2. Type a theme name
3. When I select a theme, it shows the correct colors applied in the preview mode, but when I press <ENTER>, a different theme is applied.

In this example, I select "Afterglow", and vscode applies "Abyss"

![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/760112/21712348/56945cc8-d41a-11e6-8ad3-da62a0dcd8c1.gif)

data.title: CharWidthReader performance
data.body:
The character width reader is consuming roughly ~250ms in the open editor cycle. The number is to understood with the knowledge of 'don-distortion'. That is, because it needs to layout and measure things it pays the price of all previous dom modifications, e.g from creating the workbench etc. However, there are things that can be improved

* [x] use an off-don canvas to measure character width (no possible as we have dropped support of IE9) @jrieken, @alexandrudima 
* [x] don't make the editor do the work twice. The `BaseEditor` first create an editor widget with the default config just to immediately update the config to the 'real' config @bpasero 
* [x] consider running the measure logic before the dom is 'busy'. The theory (needs confirmation) is that the measuring takes longer the more busy and dirty the render tree is @alexandrudima

data.title: Word wrapping enabled through the menu is reset whenever settings.json is modified
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
1.8.1, latest insider build
- OS Version:
Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Make sure that wrapping isn't permanently enabled, and if it is, remove any permanent setting related to wrapping.
2. Open a file that contains lines longer than the width of the screen.
3. Enable word wrapping through `View` -> `Toggle Word Wrap`.
4. Modify one character in `settings.json` and save it.
5. Word wrapping should be unexpectedly disabled.

This behavior makes extensions that modify configuration based on user actions, constantly reset the wrapping setting. For example [this issue with vscode-spellchecker](https://github.com/swyphcosmo/vscode-spellchecker/issues/24) where the wrapping is reset every time the user selects to "always ignore" a word because that action causes `settings.json` to be modified with the newly ignored word.

data.title: Annoying behavior rather than a bug: When folder is opened, all tabs are cleared/closed !
data.body:
When I open a folder and other file tabs are open, the editor closes these tabs and all edit history is deleted (so I cannot ctrl+z) and I need to open them again. 
Expected behavior: Open folder and keep existing tabs open. OR Open folder in a new window and keep other tabs in another window.

- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:49:23.350Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

data.title: Syntax highlighting broken in JSX when using arrow function's implicit return
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a `.js` file, and write some JSX in it like so:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11802078/21708284/94d486f8-d39c-11e6-91ec-2ef1149e5b1a.png)

2. Use an arrow function to implicitly return JSX.

3. Watch as the syntax highlighting below breaks.

This only breaks when the JSX is implicitly returned with the ES6 arrow function. If you wrap the JSX in parens, the syntax highlighting is not broken:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11802078/21708312/d0693b00-d39c-11e6-899b-fe611387f394.png)

Using the arrow function and using an explicit return fixes the syntax highlighting as well:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11802078/21708329/fa3fa860-d39c-11e6-83b5-eadaf5b76bd1.png)

data.title: [Typo] Change signifikant -> significant in problem matcher
data.body: Hello there, I was looking at adding support for the problem matcher object format [to Danger](https://github.com/danger/danger-js/issues/18) and spotted a typo inside the source.

data.title: TypeScript References Code Lens Provider
data.body:
Fixes #18054

Adds an initial references code lens provider implementation for JS and TS

![screen shot 2017-01-05 at 6 22 28 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/21705346/42bdab38-d374-11e6-8746-851ea6147a87.png)

Remaining work and issues:

- [x] Add setting to disable this references code lens provider.
- [x] Add some gating for TS version
- [x] Support properties as well as methods
- [x] Support access modifiers and getters and setters (added workaround, but I believe we also need a fix on TS side: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/13309)
- [x] Support classes and interfaces
- [x] Support `export const ...`
- [x] Support `export function`
- [ ] Fix `public construtor() {...}` - (needs TS: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/13330)
- [ ] Default exports (needs TS: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/11551)

We also need to investigate the perf impact of the code lens further. It will be opt in to start with

data.title: Fix Autolink Syntax Highlighting in Markdown
data.body:
Fixes #18197

**Bug**
Autolinks that start a line in markdown are currently parsed as as html content

**Fix**
Restrict the html element matcher a little more so that we don't match tags html tags that look like `<scheme:...>`

data.title: Horizontal scrolling is visually confusing
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: macOS

#### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Disable line wrapping
2. Open a file large enough to make horizontal scrolling appear
3. Scroll to the right
4. Observe that it's hard to tell where the line numbers gutter ends and the code begins

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/176815/21703532/ae6f2922-d367-11e6-99d0-dea72b09a78b.png)

#### Expectation

My expectation would be either a line shows up or a little drop shadow shows up on the line numbers when not scrolled all the way to the left, providing me a way to tell what I'm looking at.

#### Mockup

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/176815/21703573/0fd6385e-d368-11e6-9215-6633270a13a6.png)

data.title: code --wait should return control when closing window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set your EDITOR path to use VS Code and open with the Wait flag:
        export EDITOR='open -W -a Visual\ Studio\ Code'
2. Use an interactive command line tool like 'arc diff'
3. This will launch VS Code and allow you to edit a summary

Expected:
VS Code should return control to command line after I hit command-W to close the window.

Actual:
Control is only returned to the command line after completely closing VS Code via command-Q

Let me know if you need more details. Beyond Compare does a good job of this behavior where git difftool commands using BC will proceed back to the command line when a BC window is closed.

data.title: Pattern matching in "Find all files" work only for open files?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.2

Steps to Reproduce:

I have a Go project (https://github.com/ahmetalpbalkan/go-linq)  and I am looking for this pattern in the codebase: a '{' followed by two new lines.

I have no open files currently.

I hit Cmd+Shift+F and type regex: `\{\n\n`, hit the [.*] regex button and then hit return, I get no results:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/159209/21701211/359549a4-d359-11e6-9631-e8a671fcc30a.png)

Suspicious, because I am sure I have some matches.. Then I open a file `aggregate.go` and I hit Cmd+Shift+F again and return again to perform the exact same search:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/159209/21701225/4d607d56-d359-11e6-9c6f-35f6e79e628e.png)

Bam! I have matches now, but only from the open file, `aggregate.go`. Is this a bug?

data.title: Support global namespace reference in JavaScript
Continue on Multithreaded break shows other threads (besides main thread) still paused in UI
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install ms-cpptools extension 0.9.3
2. Create a multithreaded app
3. Set a breakpoint where all threads have been started
4. hit breakpoint and confirm in Call Stack window that it shows "Pause on Breakpoint"
5. hit continue -> all threads should continue, (which is what happens) but the UI still shows all threads besides main thread as "Pause on Breakpoint"

I have confirmed that we send an empty body on `ContinueResponse` but I have also tried sending `"allThreadsContinued": true` in the body with no change. The comment says if the value is not set it defaults to true.

data.title: Error using 'sidebar find / replace'

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

In my actual project, I tried to use the 'sidebar find / replace' to replace '\n ' with just '\n'. The error:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12904270/21698284/75301464-d353-11e6-8962-e3e7fadce770.png)

I then tried reproducing it on a fresh instance of VSCode with a single file. Again, using the 'sidebar find / replace', to replace '\n ' with just '\n'. There was no visible error message this time, but VSCode failed to actually make the replacement:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12904270/21698487/6d1fd16e-d354-11e6-8ccb-aeb64f36baa1.png)

I then tried using the 'single file find / replace' and it successfully made the replacement:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12904270/21698541/a78a802e-d354-11e6-8f7d-bede756f819c.png)

So the issue is with the 'sidebar find / replace' only.

data.title: Node.js debugging does not support reading from TTY
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create Node.js script that reads from command line (install https://www.npmjs.com/package/readline-sync)
```
var readlineSync = require('readline-sync');

var input = readlineSync.question('Please enter your input');

console.log(input);
```
2. Create debug config:
```
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "test",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/test.js",
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}"
        }
```

3. Debug crashes: 
```
 /dev/tty: Device not configured
stty: /dev/tty: Device not configured
/Users/xxxx/reposxxx/xxx/xxx/node_modules/readline-sync/lib/readline-sync.js:250
    if (res.error) { throw res.error; }
                     ^
Error: The current environment doesn't support interactive reading from TTY.
stty: /dev/tty: Device not configured
/Users/xxx/repos/xxx/xxx/xxx/node_modules/readline-sync/lib/read.sh: line 49: /dev/tty: Device not configured
stty: /dev/tty: Device not configured
    at readlineExt (/Users/xxx/repos/xxx/xxx/xxx-client/node_modules/readline-sync/lib/readline-sync.js:212:19)
    at tryExt (/Users/xxx/repos/xxx/xxx/xxx-client/node_modules/readline-sync/lib/readline-sync.js:249:15)
    at /Users/xxx/repos/xxx/xxx/xxx-client/node_modules/readline-sync/lib/readline-sync.js:352:15
    at _readlineSync (/Users/xxx/repos/xxx/xxx/xxx-client/node_modules/readline-sync/lib/readline-sync.js:426:5)
    at getValidLine (/Users/xxx/repos/xxx/xxx/xxx-client/node_modules/readline-sync/lib/readline-sync.js:756:11)
    at Object.exports.question (/Users/xxx/repos/xxx/xxx/xxx-client/node_modules/readline-sync/lib/readline-sync.js:838:10)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/xxx/repos/xxx/xxx/xxx-client/test.js:3:29)
    at Module._compile (module.js:570:32)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:579:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:487:32)
```

data.title: [bash] commands after HEREDOC delimiter are highlighted like the HEREDOC
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a Shell Script
2. Paste 
```
# grab field types from ORACLE
sqlplus -s user/pass << EOD | sed '/^$/d' | awk 'NR>2{print}' > temp.txt
SET PAGESIZE 0;
SET FEEDBACK OFF;
DESCRIBE $1;
EOD
```

everything after the end of heredoc token **EOD** is highlighted the same as the rest of the heredoc.

data.title: VS Code Crashed with "The Window Has Crashed"

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows Server 2008 R2

Just installed Visual Studio Code on a VM running Windows Server 2008 R2. The installation ends with launching Visual Studio Code, then the CPU usage hits the roof and some minutes later Code is launched but with the  "The window has crashed" dialog. I try the Reopen button but it will just repeat itself. I have no choice but to close the window but that also mean I can't launch Visual Studio Code at all
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch Visual Studio Code by either
      a. click the desktop icon
      b. right click the desktop icon and select "Run As Administrator"
      c. run Code in command line prompt
      d. run "Code -n" in command line prompt
      e. run Code in a command windows running as Administrator

All of the above result in the same error

data.title: Export more git commands
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.8.1 (1.8.1)
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add `workbench.action.git.stageRanges` as a keybinding
2. Try to run with selected text in a diff view

Expected:
The selected lines get staged.

Experienced:
Editor gives a warning with `command 'workbench.action.git.stageRanges' not found`

I know that this command is not officially documented (in the provided `keybindings.json`), still I would like to know if:
1. there is reason for that
2. it should work.
